bibl.title: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, July 9, 1906

div1.p: Carroll gives Latimer permission to quote from letters that he provided to her. He objects to their characterization of his work after Walter Reed's experiments.

div1.head: Letter from James Carroll to Caroline Latimer, July 9, 1906
div1.p:
Upon
thinking over the subject of
our conversation on Saturday
I have concluded that your
candid treatment of the subject
should entitle you to use any
of the letters in any portions of
them you may think fit. I
leave the matter entirely in the
discretion of yourself and Dr Kelly.

It amuses me now when I think
how I went ahead with those experiments
producing six cases after Reed had ad-
vised against it; using some of Guiteras'
mosquitoes to start with immediately
after the conclusion of his work and
in spite of the protests of Guiteras and Dr
Ross, the director of the hospital; as-
suming the grave responsibility at a time
when public opinion would have been against
it -- then to hear that that was not initiative,
that it was simply the work of an assistant!
Many thanks for your courtesy on Saturday.
